question_details.title: Will the Project 2025 Tracker spreadsheet mark the objective of reducing regulations on cryptocurrencies as complete on April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: At the time of this question, the objective was marked as "in progress." The 2025 Tracker is a project of the Keep\_Track subreddit and is explained [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/Keep_Track/comments/1ii7tbr/project_2025_tracker_is_now_live/).
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Project 2025 objective to "reduce regulations on cryptocurrencies" is marked as complete according to [this spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QGG6wNHna-1tt91yXNkOauAJJ7snobFjfEnmxlmzhl4/edit?gid=0#gid=0) when accessed by Metaculus on or after April 1, 2025.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**European Commission Adopts Delegated Regulation on Cryptoasset Transparency**
The European Commission has adopted a delegated regulation (EU) 2025/417, which complements the Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and the Council on technical standards for regulation in the field of cryptoassets. The regulation requires providers of cryptoasset services that manage a trading platform to make certain information publicly available, including prices, order books, and transaction data. The regulation also requires the desegregation of pre-trade and post-trade data, and the provision of this data to any interested party upon request. The regulation will enter into force 20 days after its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 13, 2025 11:00 PM
Source:[Boletín Oficial del Estado - BOE](https://www.boe.es/buscar/doc.php?id=DOUE-L-2025-80438)

**Argentina Publishes New Regulation for Cryptocurrency Exchanges**
The Argentine government has published a new regulation for cryptocurrency exchanges, following the scandal surrounding the Libra cryptocurrency. The Comisión Nacional de Valores (CNV) has created a framework for companies that sell digital assets in Argentina, which includes requirements, obligations, and prohibitions. The regulation aims to ensure transparency, stability, and protection of users in the cryptocurrency ecosystem. According to the CNV, 'the same has the objective of guaranteeing transparency, stability and protection of users in the crypto ecosystem, imposing obligations in matters of registration, cybersecurity, custody of assets, prevention of money laundering and disclosure of risks.' The regulation includes provisions such as the separation of client assets, requirements for cybersecurity and data protection, and the prohibition of using client cryptocurrencies. The regulation will come into effect on December 31, 2025, and companies that do not comply with the requirements and deadlines will not be able to operate in Argentina. 'We have worked a lot on this norm with the objective of making it effective and comply with the Law, maintaining a balance to not overregulate or impose unnecessary costs on the industry, promoting innovation. This work has been joint with all the actors of the sector, who have made their contributions through the public consultation, which are incorporated in this normative,' said the president of the CNV, Roberto Silva.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 13, 2025 08:23 PM
Source:[La Nacion](https://www.lanacion.com.ar/economia/prohibiciones-y-obligaciones-tras-el-escandalo-de-libra-el-gobierno-publico-una-norma-para-regular-nid13032025/)

**Argentina Strengthens Regulations for Cryptocurrency Wallets**
The Argentine government has strengthened the requirements for cryptocurrency wallets to operate in the country through Resolution General 1058. The new regulations, which were prompted by a request from the Financial Action Task Force (GAFI), require Providers of Virtual Asset Services (PSAV) to meet additional requirements to continue operating. The regulations aim to prevent Argentina from being added to the GAFI's gray list. The first step was the creation of a PSAV registry, which now has 140 registered companies and 140 in the process of registration. However, the new regulations require registered companies to revalidate their intention to operate by meeting the new requirements. The key points of the regulation include: the deadline for compliance is 1 July 2024 for individuals, 1 August 2025 for local companies, and 1 September 2025 for foreign companies; the deadline for adapting the operational structure is the end of the year; and the regulation and sanctions will come into full effect on 31 December 2025. The National Securities Commission (CNV) can suspend or revoke registrations and unregistered PSAV can be blocked by court order. The regulation was subject to public consultation between October and December 2024 and was not delayed despite the Libra scandal. The government aims to have the regulation in full effect by 2026, giving the industry time to adapt. The regulation is focused on wallets, not cryptocurrencies, and does not include the Solana blockchain or memecoins, which are not considered negotiable assets.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 13, 2025 07:29 PM
Source:[Todo Noticias](https://tn.com.ar/economia/2025/03/13/el-gobierno-endurecio-los-requisitos-que-deben-cumplir-las-billeteras-cripto-para-operar-en-la-argentina/)

**Argentina's CNV Publishes New Regulations for Cryptocurrency Exchanges**
The Comisión Nacional de Valores (CNV) has published the new regulations for cryptocurrency exchanges in Argentina. The new rules require providers of virtual asset services to have a minimum net worth, report custody details, comply with cybersecurity and anti-money laundering norms, and have a public relations officer. Additionally, exchanges must list memecoins created within the last 90 days in a special section, warning users of the 'risk of total loss' and 'volatility' associated with this investment. According to CNV, 'the goal is to ensure transparency, stability, and user protection in the cryptocurrency ecosystem', imposing obligations in terms of registration, cybersecurity, asset custody, anti-money laundering, and risk disclosure. Roberto Silva, CNV president, explained that 'we have worked hard on this norm, maintaining a balance to avoid over-regulation and unnecessary costs for the industry, promoting innovation.' The regulation is not related to the LIBRA case, and its timing is not linked to the token promoted by Javier Milei. Currently, 140 entities are registered with CNV, with 131 being legal entities and 9 being individuals. The new regulations will come into effect on December 31, 2025.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 13, 2025 07:22 PM
Source:[El Cronista](https://www.cronista.com/finanzas-mercados/regulacion-cripto-2-0-todos-los-detalles-de-la-nueva-norma-de-cnv/)

**Crypto crackdown: Major exchanges are losing millions over compliance failures - Businessday NG**
Major cryptocurrency exchanges have been fined hundreds of millions of dollars in 2025 for failing to comply with financial regulations. Regulators are cracking down on non-compliance, with exchanges facing operational bans, lawsuits, and damage to their reputation. This is a wake-up call for crypto users and businesses, especially in Africa, where digital assets are growing rapidly. Governments worldwide are enforcing compliance, and businesses that fail to follow regulations are facing severe consequences. Exchanges must follow Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Know Your Customer (KYC) regulations, and crypto transactions are being monitored. Non-compliance leads to heavy fines, business shutdowns, and even criminal charges. The future of crypto regulation includes stronger KYC and AML rules, more fines and penalties, and greater clarity in crypto laws. 'Crypto is not beyond the law,' and governments are serious about enforcement. 'The future belongs to those who understand the rules and play by them.'
Original language: en
Publish date: March 13, 2025 06:27 PM
Source:[Businessday NG](https://businessday.ng/opinion/article/crypto-crackdown-major-exchanges-are-losing-millions-over-compliance-failures/)

**Russian Central Bank seeks to ban cryptocurrency, except for wealthy**
The Central Bank of Russia has proposed restricting cryptocurrency transactions to 'particularly qualified investors' who possess over RUB 100 million (US$1.1 million) in securities or have earned more than RUB 50 million (US$560,000) per year. For other citizens, cryptocurrency transactions may be prohibited, with penalties introduced for violations. The Central Bank reaffirmed that it does not consider cryptocurrency as a means of payment and plans to ban crypto transactions between Russian residents and impose regulatory requirements on financial institutions seeking to invest in digital assets. This proposal comes after Russia allowed international settlements in cryptocurrency under an experimental legal framework in September 2024 and legalised cryptocurrency mining in November 2024, with new tax regulations for miners taking effect in 2025.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 13, 2025 04:32 PM
Source:[Українська правда](https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2025/03/13/7502741/)

**Turkey's New Regulations for Cryptocurrency Sector: A Secure Ecosystem and Investor Protection**
The Capital Markets Board (CMB) in Turkey has published new regulations for the cryptocurrency sector, aiming to create a secure ecosystem and protect investors. The regulations require cryptocurrency service providers to be established as joint-stock companies, have a minimum founding capital of 150 million TL for platforms and 500 million TL for custody institutions, and hold at least 95% of customer assets in custody institutions authorized by the Board. Platforms will only be able to hold 5% of customer assets in-house, and customer cash will be held in accounts opened with banks, monitored separately from the platform's own accounts. The regulations also introduce detailed rules for activities such as buying and selling of cryptocurrencies, initial sales or distributions, custody, and investment advisory, as well as technical requirements such as price monitoring systems and independent audits of information systems. Existing cryptocurrency platforms must apply for an operating license by June 30, 2025, and meet capital adequacy requirements and other obligations by the same date. The regulations aim to provide a legal framework for the cryptocurrency ecosystem in Turkey, but the high capital requirements may lead to consolidation in the sector and make it difficult for small-scale platforms to continue their operations.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 13, 2025 08:05 AM
Source:[Haberler.com](https://en.haberler.com/a-new-era-in-turkey-s-cryptocurrency-sector-18445556/?utm_source=facebook&utm_campaign=tavsiye_et)

**Official Gazette Publishes Various Regulations and Decisions**
The Official Gazette (Resmi Gazete) has published several regulations and decisions on March 13, 2025. These include administrative regulations, announcements, and decisions from various institutions. The regulations include changes to the rules for the supervision and control of vehicles, systems, and technical units, as well as new rules for the protection and sustainable use of domestic animal genetic resources. The announcements include changes to the classification of workplace hazards and the rules for the establishment and operation of cryptocurrency service providers. The decisions include the results of the Nuclear Regulation Council's meeting on March 6, 2025, and several decisions from the Constitutional Court, including decisions on political party financial supervision.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 13, 2025 05:18 AM
Source:[NTV](https://www.ntv.com.tr/turkiye/resmi-gazetede-bugun-13-mart-2025-resmi-gazete-kararlari,5_Fu1A-6FEmHjIQw--zDWg)

**Official Gazette Publishes Key Decisions and Regulations on March 13, 2025**
The Official Gazette (Resmî Gazete) published its decisions, regulations, and decrees on March 13, 2025. The following are some of the key publications: The Administrative Regulations on the Market Supervision and Control of Vehicles, Systems, and Separate Technical Units (AB/2022/163) was published. Additionally, there were changes made to the Regulation on the Protection and Sustainable Use of Livestock Genetic Resources and the Regulation on the Registration of Livestock Genetic Resources. Other notable publications include the Decree on the Amendment to the Regulation on Workplace Safety and Health Risk Classes, the Decree on the Establishment and Operation of Cryptocurrency Service Providers, and the Decree on the Amendment to the Regulation on Independent Auditing of Information Systems. The Nuclear Regulatory Board also made a decision on March 6, 2025. The Constitutional Court made several decisions on December 5, 25, and 25, 2024, regarding various cases. Finally, the Official Gazette published various announcements, including court decisions, tender announcements, and other notices.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 12, 2025 09:04 PM
Source:[T24](https://t24.com.tr/haber/resmi-gazete-de-bugun-13-mart-2025-resmi-gazete-kararlari,1225440)

**Italian Government Holds High-Level Meeting on Cryptocurrency Regulation**
The Italian government has held a high-level meeting at Palazzo Chigi to discuss the regulation of cryptocurrencies. The meeting, presided over by Undersecretary Alfredo Mantovano, included ministers Giancarlo Giorgetti and Matteo Piantedosi, as well as the Governor of the Bank of Italy, Fabio Panetta, and other top officials. The meeting focused on the upcoming deadline of June 30, 2025, by which time service providers for cryptocurrency activities must apply for authorization to operate in Italy according to EU harmonized rules. The new regulations aim to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, and will require service providers to demonstrate adequate organizational and control arrangements. The meeting also discussed the pros and cons of Bitcoin and other digital currencies, amidst the backdrop of a recent executive order by US President Donald Trump to create a 'Strategic Bitcoin Reserve'.
Original language: it
Publish date: March 12, 2025 07:23 PM
Source:[Il Sole 24 ORE](https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/criptovalute-vertice-palazzo-chigi-bankitalia-007-e-agenzia-la-cybersicurezza-vista-scadenza-giugno-AG2WKiUD)

**Palazzo Chigi Meeting on Cryptocurrencies: A Step Towards Regulation**
A meeting was held at Palazzo Chigi to discuss cryptocurrencies, focusing on the Dlgs 129/2024 law in preparation for the June 30, 2025 deadline, by which time entities operating in Italy in the crypto-activity sector must submit an authorization request. The law is in line with the MiCAR regulation, which introduces a harmonized regulatory framework for virtual currencies. The meeting was chaired by Undersecretary Alfredo Mantovano, and attended by ministers Giancarlo Giorgetti, Matteo Piantedosi, and Fabio Panetta, Governor of the Bank of Italy, as well as other high-ranking officials. The Consob and the Bank of Italy had previously signed a protocol of intent to define the areas of cooperation between the two authorities in light of the MiCAR regulation. The regulation has been completed by the decree-law n. 129/2024, which has attributed regulatory, informative, supervisory, and sanctioning powers to the Consob and the Bank of Italy on entities offering, issuing, or providing services related to cryptocurrencies. The protocol will regulate the modalities of exercise of the regulatory powers of the two authorities in cases where opinions or agreements are required, and will define the exchange of information acquired in the context of their respective controls and collaboration with other European authorities.
Original language: it
Publish date: March 12, 2025 07:55 PM
Source:[La Repubblica](https://finanza.repubblica.it/News/2025/03/12/a_palazzo_chigi_riunione_su_criptovalute_presente_anche_il_governatore_di_bankitalia_panetta-223/)

**New Era in Cryptocurrency Transfers: 15,000 TL Threshold for Identification**
A new regulation has been implemented in the cryptocurrency market, requiring identification information for transactions over 15,000 Turkish Lira. According to the regulation, the sender and recipient's identification information, including name, surname, and address, must be provided for transactions over 15,000 Turkish Lira. Additionally, the authenticity of this information will be verified, and users who fail to provide complete information will be unable to complete transactions. This regulation aims to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. Binance, a major cryptocurrency exchange, has announced that it will close accounts that do not undergo identity verification by April 25, 2025. The new regulation aims to create a more transparent and secure environment in the cryptocurrency market.
Original language: tr
Publish date: February 26, 2025 11:38 AM
Source:[yaylahaber.com.tr](https://www.yaylahaber.com.tr/kripto-para-transferlerinde-yeni-donem-15-bin-tl-uzerinde-kimlik-sarti-geldi)

**Turkey Introduces New Cryptocurrency Regulations to Prevent Money Laundering**
Turkey's new cryptocurrency regulation, implemented on February 25, 2025, requires identification for transactions exceeding 15,000 TL, and restricts accounts without identity verification by April. The regulation, led by MASAK, aims to prevent money laundering and terrorism financing. Cryptocurrency platforms will collect identification information, including name, trade registry number, or wallet address, and verify its accuracy. Accounts without identity verification will be restricted, with open positions closed and deposit and withdrawal transactions suspended. The regulation grants service providers the authority to request additional documents for transactions below 15,000 TL, and stricter identity verification procedures will be applied for privacy-focused cryptocurrencies. The Capital Markets Board has granted licenses to 88 cryptocurrency companies, and a new category 'digital assets' has been created in financial reporting to enhance transparency. According to Chainalysis data, Turkey's transaction volume is approximately 170 billion dollars, and the regulations are expected to reduce the informal economy.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 08:11 AM
Source:[Haberler.com](https://en.haberler.com/a-new-era-has-begun-for-cryptocurrency-2058624/?utm_source=facebook&utm_campaign=tavsiye_et)

**New Regulation Requires Identification Information for Cryptocurrency Transactions Exceeding 15,000 Turkish Lira**
A new regulation has been implemented in the cryptocurrency market, requiring identification information for transactions exceeding 15,000 Turkish Lira. According to the new regulation, for transactions exceeding 15,000 Turkish Lira, the sender and recipient's name, registered trade name, full name of legal entities, and wallet address must be obtained. If the wallet address is not found, other information such as reference number, address, place of birth, citizenship number, customer number, passport number, or tax identification number must be obtained. Additionally, the accuracy of this information must be verified. For unregistered wallet addresses, at least one of the above-mentioned information must be obtained from the customer. For transactions under 15,000 Turkish Lira, only the basic information of the sender and recipient, such as their names and wallet addresses, must be obtained. However, verification of this information is not mandatory for cryptocurrency service providers. In high-risk transactions, additional measures may be taken, such as requesting more information and documents from customers. If sufficient information cannot be obtained, the transfer may not be made, or the customer's account may be restricted or terminated. Binance, a cryptocurrency exchange, has also announced that it will close accounts that do not complete the identity verification process by April 25, 2025. During this period, users who do not complete the identity verification process will not be able to access their accounts, and their open positions will be closed, and they will not be able to make or receive transactions.
Original language: tr
Publish date: February 26, 2025 07:41 AM
Source:[Haberler](https://www.haberler.com/ekonomi/kripto-paralar-icin-yeni-zorunluluk-basliyor-18410396-haberi/)

**New Regulations for Cryptocurrency Transactions in Turkey: Identification Required for Transactions Over 15,000 TL**
New regulations for cryptocurrency transactions have come into effect, requiring identification for transactions over 15,000 TL. The regulations, published on December 25, 2024, aim to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. According to the new rules, for transactions over 15,000 TL, the sender's name, title, and wallet address must be provided. For transactions under 15,000 TL, the sender's name and wallet address are required. The regulations also require cryptocurrency service providers to verify the identity of their customers and to report suspicious transactions. Binance, a popular cryptocurrency exchange, has announced that it will close accounts without identification by April 25, 2025, and will not allow users to make any transactions.
Original language: tr
Publish date: February 25, 2025 07:39 PM
Source:[indigodergisi.com](https://indigodergisi.com/2025/02/kripto-yatiriminda-15-bin-tl-uzerine-kimlik-zorunlulugu/)

**Turkey Introduces New Cryptocurrency Regulations**
A new regulation on cryptocurrency transactions in Turkey, which came into effect on February 25, 2025, requires identification for transactions over 15,000 TL and will restrict accounts that do not complete the identification process by the end of April. The regulation, led by MASAK, aims to prevent the laundering of criminal proceeds and combat terrorist financing. According to the new rules, both the sender and recipient of cryptocurrency transactions over 15,000 TL must provide their identification information, which includes at least one identifying information such as name, trade register, wallet address, or reference number. Cryptocurrency exchange platforms in Turkey have announced that they will restrict the accounts of users who do not complete the identification process by April 25, 2025. The restriction will include closing open positions and temporarily suspending all account functions, including deposit and withdrawal. The regulation does not require identification for transactions under 15,000 TL, but gives service providers the authority to request additional documents in cases where necessary. The regulation aims to increase the transparency and security of the cryptocurrency market in Turkey, which is the world's fourth-largest cryptocurrency market with a transaction volume of approximately $170 billion, according to Chainalysis data. Industry experts emphasize that the new regulations are important steps towards a controlled cryptocurrency market and that users' timely completion of identification processes and service providers' strengthening of their technical infrastructure will play a critical role in preventing disruptions.
Original language: tr
Publish date: February 25, 2025 06:17 PM
Source:[Haberler](https://www.haberler.com/kripto-para/turkiye-de-kripto-para-islemleri-icin-yeni-donem-18409631-haberi/)

**Important Change in Cryptocurrency Transfers: New Regulations Come into Effect**
New regulations for cryptocurrency transfers in Turkey have come into effect as of February 25, 2025. The rules, published in the Official Gazette on December 25, 2024, require stricter monitoring of cryptocurrency transfers exceeding 15,000 TL. According to the new regulations, cryptocurrency exchanges must now keep more detailed records of transactions. For transactions over 15,000 TL, the following information must be obtained from the sender: name, title, full name of the company, wallet address, and at least one of the following: reference number, address, date of birth, citizenship number, customer number, passport number, or tax identification number. This information will be verified to make it easier to identify the sender. Binance, a cryptocurrency exchange, has announced that it will close accounts without identification by April 25, 2025, and close open positions of users who have not completed the identification process.
Original language: tr
Publish date: February 25, 2025 02:17 PM
Source:[tgrthaber.com](https://www.tgrthaber.com/ekonomi/kripto-para-transferleri-ile-ilgili-onemli-degisiklik-15-bin-tl-uzeri-gonderimler-ici-3204648)

**Biggest Crypto Crackdowns of 2025**
The cryptocurrency industry, valued at around $1.4 trillion, is facing stricter regulations worldwide. Governments have been increasing regulations until February 2025 to combat fraud, manipulation, money laundering, security threats, and the risk of using digital currencies for illicit purposes. This crackdown aims to promote regulatory compliance and protect investors. The future of digital currencies remains uncertain, but stricter regulations may provide a safer environment for investors.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 22, 2025 11:04 AM
Source:[Analytics Insight](https://www.analyticsinsight.net/cryptocurrency-analytics-insight/biggest-crypto-crackdowns-of-2025)

**Crypto in the White House: How US Policies Might Change in 2025**
President Donald Trump signed an executive order on January 23, 2025, to promote digital financial technology and create clear regulations for cryptocurrency. The order replaces the previous administration's cautious approach with a focus on economic growth. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) also announced new policies, including revoking rules that discouraged banks from offering crypto custody services. The SEC Crypto Task Force, led by Commissioner Hester Peirce, will focus on clear regulations instead of enforcement actions. The new policies aim to foster the development of US dollar-backed stablecoins and prohibit the creation of a central bank digital currency for the US. The President's Working Group on Digital Asset Markets will oversee the coordination of digital asset efforts and provide policy recommendations by July 2025. Federal agencies are required to analyze current regulations and propose changes by March. The executive order promotes self-custody of digital assets and provides legal protections for software developers, miners, and blockchain validators. It also instructs officials to consider building a cryptocurrency reserve, with some lawmakers advocating for a Bitcoin-centric reserve and others suggesting a wider range of cryptocurrencies.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2025 07:32 PM
Source:[Analytics Insight](https://www.analyticsinsight.net/cryptocurrency-analytics-insight/crypto-in-the-white-house-how-us-policies-might-change-in-2025)

**New Administration Action on Cryptocurrency Tax Regulations**
The new administration has taken action on cryptocurrency tax regulations. President Trump signed an executive order on January 23, 2025, creating a Working Group on Digital Assets to identify federal regulations and recommend policy changes. The order opposes the creation of a United States Central Bank Digital Currency and signals that certain cryptocurrencies could be treated as currency for tax purposes. Congress is also taking action, with several members proposing to revoke recent Treasury regulations that require decentralized finance platforms to provide Form 1099 reports as brokers do. The IRS will continue to enforce compliance within existing U.S. federal income tax framework, but may extend 1099 reporting rules to foreign brokers. Taxpayers and professionals are left without clarity on their status or prioritization due to the hold on existing cryptocurrency tax regulatory projects.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2025 03:40 PM
Source:[JD Supra](https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/new-administration-action-on-6975392/)

**Crypto Regulations: Global Policies to Watch in 2025**
The global cryptocurrency market capitalization stands at approximately $3.18 trillion, with Bitcoin (BTC) trading at around $97,906 and Ethereum (ETH) at $2,665.85. Governments worldwide are paying closer attention to regulatory frameworks due to the increasing adoption of digital assets. The US SEC has launched a new 'Crypto Task Force' to introduce a clearer regulatory agenda. Countries like Japan, Singapore, and the UAE are refining their legal frameworks to foster innovation while ensuring compliance, while others like China, India, and Russia are taking a more cautious stance. In 2025, governments are prioritizing security, transparency, and anti-money laundering (AML) compliance, making it essential for investors, businesses, and policymakers to stay informed about the evolving landscape.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 07:07 AM
Source:[Analytics Insight](https://www.analyticsinsight.net/cryptocurrency-analytics-insight/crypto-regulations-global-policies-to-watch-in-2025)

**Asset Management Regulatory Year in Review 2024**
The article provides an overview of the regulatory changes in the asset management industry globally in 2024. The regulatory activity was wide-ranging and without a unifying theme, requiring asset managers to closely review what has happened and keep tabs on what is likely to happen going forward. The article highlights key developments in the United States, including the SEC's adoption of amendments to mutual fund liquidity regulations, the SEC's climate-related risk disclosure rules, and the SEC's enforcement actions against cryptocurrency exchanges and projects. The article also discusses global developments, including the adoption of sustainability and impact investment laws in Asia, the introduction of a capital gains tax in Singapore, and the regulation of digital assets in the Middle East. The article concludes by looking ahead to 2025, which promises to be a busy year for asset managers with new regulatory requirements and opportunities. Key metrics mentioned in the article include: - 2024 was a year of meaningful regulatory change for asset managers globally. - The SEC adopted amendments to mutual fund liquidity regulations requiring significant additional disclosure and making targeted changes to the substantive requirements. - The SEC's climate-related risk disclosure rules were adopted, but were subject to legal challenges and are unlikely to come into effect. - The SEC's enforcement actions against cryptocurrency exchanges and projects continued, with the SEC pursuing legal action against exchanges and projects for alleged unregistered securities offerings. - The SEC approved the listing and registration of spot Bitcoin and Ether exchange-traded products (ETPs). - The SEC adopted amendments to Regulation S-P, enhancing privacy-related protections and obligations. - The SEC adopted amendments to Form PF, impacting private fund advisers, to enhance regulatory oversight of hedge funds, improve data quality, and increase transparency. 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[jdsupra.com](https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/asset-management-regulatory-year-in-8173382/)

**Regulation for Cryptocurrency Exchanges is Coming**
Regulatory work on cryptocurrency exchanges has been completed. As part of this, rules on the storage and transfer of cryptocurrencies will be clarified. In the new period, prices will be monitored, committees will be formed for listings, and leverage transactions will be prohibited. Sanctions will be applied for market-disrupting actions. The Secondary Regulation Work on Cryptocurrency Service Providers, which was carried out by the Capital Markets Board of the Ministry of Treasury and Finance, has been completed. The draft regulations on the establishment and operation of cryptocurrency service providers, their working procedures and principles, and their capital adequacy, were prepared while taking into account the opinions of relevant public institutions and the sector. The draft regulations specify the conditions for the founders, shareholders, managers, and employees of cryptocurrency service providers.
Original language: tr
Publish date: January 23, 2025 01:29 PM
Source:[Yeni Akit Gazetesi](https://www.yeniakit.com.tr/foto-galeri/calismada-sona-gelindi-kripto-para-borsalarina-duzenleme-geliyor-103692)

**Senator Tim Scott Unveils Plan to Overhaul U.S. Cryptocurrency Regulation Framework in 2025**
Senator Tim Scott has unveiled a plan to overhaul U.S. cryptocurrency regulation in 2025, aiming to foster innovation, ensure consumer protection, and strengthen economic security. Scott's proposed framework includes tailored guidelines for digital assets, compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act, and initiatives to promote financial inclusion. He emphasized the need to balance regulatory oversight with flexibility to maintain the U.S.'s position as a leader in the global crypto market. Scott also pledged bipartisan collaboration to develop comprehensive solutions that enhance financial inclusion and economic opportunities nationwide, stating, 'My goal for this Congress is simple: make America work for Americans.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 22, 2025 04:31 PM
Source:[crypto-news.net](https://www.crypto-news.net/senator-tim-scott-unveils-plan-to-overhaul-u-s/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To forecast this event, I'll begin by establishing an initial probability based on historical frequency. In recent years, the global trend for cryptocurrency regulation has shown varying patterns: certain regions have tightened controls, while others have relaxed regulations to foster innovation. Based on a review of major economies and historical precedence in cryptocurrency regulation changes over a few months, about 20% of planned regulatory changes are completed in a one-month timeframe for projects driven by online communities, which tend to have dispersed influence and bureaucratic challenges.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Online Community Dynamics
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Projects driven by online communities often face organizational and consensus challenges, leading to delays. The Keep_Track subreddit may have difficulties in coordinating effectively to push for a significant regulatory change in such a short time frame.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Regulatory Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There has been a trend towards increased scrutiny in cryptocurrency regulation globally due to concerns around fraud, security, and financial stability. This cautious approach means regulatory bodies are more likely to delay significant deregulation efforts.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political and Economic Incentives
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Governments may be incentivized to deregulate to stimulate economic growth or to attract cryptocurrency businesses. If economic indicators favor such a move, there may be a slight increase in probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological and Industry Developments
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Technological advancements and industry shifts can sometimes pressure regulators to loosen restrictions to foster innovation. However, this typically occurs over longer periods than a couple of weeks.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The recent news articles indicate an overall trend towards increased regulation and scrutiny in the cryptocurrency sector globally. The European Commission's new regulation and Argentina's stricter measures highlight this consistent regulatory tightening. Turkey's new regulations for identification in cryptocurrency transactions further support this pattern of increased regulatory oversight.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: No significant news articles suggest that current regulations on cryptocurrencies are being reduced or that there is substantial momentum towards deregulation. Instead, the focus remains on enhancing compliance and regulatory controls.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, the implementation of regulatory changes in the cryptocurrency space has been slow and often met with resistance due to the complexities involved. The base rate of successful, rapid deregulation in established financial systems is relatively low. perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological and Market Volatility
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The cryptocurrency market is highly volatile, and sudden shifts (e.g., significant price changes, technological breakthroughs, security issues) can influence regulatory processes. Regulators may pause to reassess their approaches in response to such changes.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The recent global news indicates multiple countries are imposing new regulations and restrictions on cryptocurrencies, including heightened compliance requirements and stricter monitoring policies. These steps demonstrate a trend towards increased regulation, not a reduction.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There is no evidence or news suggesting a specific initiative to reduce regulations on cryptocurrency within the short timeframe by April 1, 2025. Rather, most updates reflect an increase in regulatory activities.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: The overall trend in cryptocurrency regulation worldwide has been towards more regulation, not less, especially after incidents like the FTX collapse in 2022, which led many jurisdictions to tighten their control over cryptocurrencies. Historically, efforts to reduce regulation require significant political and economic motivation. Given the current regulatory environment, the base rate for countries reducing regulations on cryptocurrencies within a short time frame is low. As such, I estimate the initial probability of the objective being marked 'complete' by April 1, 2025, at 20%, considering global regulatory trends.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Public Demand for Cryptocurrency Regulation
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is increasing public demand for regulation due to high-profile incidents involving fraud and mismanagement within the crypto space. This demand for oversight makes it less likely that current regulations will be reduced, adding stability to the existing legal framework.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological Lobbying
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The technology sector, including many influential companies and lobbyists, continues to push for favorable cryptocurrency regulations. This lobbying effort could lead to some reduction in regulation in specific areas if political conditions are favorable.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Legislative Changes
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If recent legislative actions suggest a move towards deregulation or more crypto-friendly policies, this could significantly influence the outcome, especially if there is momentum towards embodying such changes. However, no major sweeping deregulations have been indicated recently that suggest imminent completion of the objective.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The majority of the news articles highlight an increase in regulatory actions aimed at enhancing transparency, security, and compliance in the cryptocurrency sector. For instance, the European Commission adopted a regulation requiring greater transparency from crypto asset service providers, and Argentina introduced new regulations to ensure user protection and stability in the crypto ecosystem. Similarly, Turkey implemented new rules requiring identification for large crypto transactions, emphasizing anti-money laundering and security compliance.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: A potential factor challenging the prior analysis is the U.S. administration's shift towards clearer regulations and economic growth in the crypto sector, as indicated by President Trump's executive order. However, these changes primarily focus on fostering digital financial technology rather than reducing existing regulations.

summary: After analyzing the predictions from the experts across two phases, the consensus is that the probability of the Project 2025 Tracker spreadsheet marking the objective of reducing regulations on cryptocurrencies as complete on April 1, 2025, is very low. In Phase 1, initial probabilities ranged from 5% to 50%, with most experts estimating between 20% and 30%. Factors such as complex regulatory environments, institutional resistance, and recent trends towards increased global regulation contributed to these estimates. In Phase 2, after reviewing recent news articles, experts generally revised their probabilities downwards or maintained low estimates, with a significant emphasis on the global trend of stricter regulations and increased compliance requirements in regions like the EU, Turkey, and Argentina. The U.S. administration's potential shift towards clearer regulations was noted but deemed insufficient to significantly alter the global trend towards increased regulation. The final revised probabilities mostly fell between 0% and 25%, indicating a strong consensus that the objective is unlikely to be marked as complete by the specified date.
